awd_titl_txt: OPUS: CRS Synthesizing long-term data to forecast native understory plant community structure & dynamics with invasion--species interactions, abiotic change & physiology
awd_abstract_narration:
Forests in many parts of the world are negatively impacted by both high populations of native ungulates herbivores (deer, moose, elk) and non-native invasive plants. This project will explore overabundant herbivores’ and invaders’ impacts at the individual, population, and community levels for common native perennial wildflowers of forests. The project has three goals: 1. Determine the relative effect and importance of deer herbivory, invasion, and surrounding plant neighborhood on individual wildflower population’s persistence using a community coexistence model. 2. Evaluate how the anthropogenic stressors (deer, invasion) interact and forecast future forest wildflower composition under the different scenarios created in the long-term experiment. 3. Share the wildflower databases and collaborate with artists/designers on students’ training in design. Undergraduates will create products such as virtual reality experiences, apps, or board games. Since US forests often experience both high deer populations and invasion by non-native plants, the results of the community models will be applicable at wide regional scales for basic scientists and land managers; the student products will foster a broader public understanding of ongoing changes to our forests. 

The project will use individual wildflower databases and abiotic data collected with NSF support to build a cohesive community model and to project community coexistence using four biotic and abiotic interaction landscapes imposed by a long-term field experiment. The planned analyses will use growth, survival, flowering and seed production databases for each wildflower species collected in the long-term field experiment, in which the presence of both white-tailed deer and a noxious plant invader are manipulated for nearly two decades. This approach is novel, in that rather than being phenomenological or applying simulations, it will build a mechanistic, process-based model to assess understory community coexistence leveraging data from long-term experimental treatments. This modeling will add value to prior individual or pair-wise interaction studies by providing a unified framework to assess critical links and interactions between biotic stressors, environmental characteristics, and species’ population dynamics to forecast future community dynamics and composition. Undergraduate students will be trained in data visualization using the same long-term databases used in the community modeling of the forest understory. The design process, “Act > Reflect > Change”, requires students to define and explore connections between the specific content they attempt to visualize and refine their product for their target audiences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Anthropogenic changes in the environment have resulted in shifts in biotic interactions and abiotic conditions within forest ecosystems.  These shifts drive dramatic changes in the demographic dynamics of individual native plant species in the understory. Disentangling the causal mechanisms driving these shifts is fundamental to understanding how current biodiversity is organized and to project and maintain future biodiversity across space and time.

Three sets of Core Articles from prior NSF funding that examined ecology, demography, and physiology of a group of common native understory herbs were synthesized to assess future forest community composition. Core Articles I address direct and indirect interactions of herbivores or invasion on abiotic conditions in the forest and population-level fitness of individual species. Core Articles II explore the phenological and physiological traits, light responses, and carbon budget strategies of understory herbs. Core Articles III investigate the mechanisms through which invaders disrupt the plant-AMF symbiosis and change the soil AMF community composition. The OPUS project unifies these distinct projects using a novel cohesive community model to scale up from pairwise interactions to project community coexistence. Plant demographic databases generated in 20-year field experiment, which manipulated the presence of both an overabundant herbivore and an allelopathic plant invader addressed three goals: 1. Determine the relative importance of deer, invasion, light, herbivory, Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Fungi (AMF) that form a nutritional mutualism in plant roots, soil resources, and surrounding plant neighborhood for individual plant species and coexistence in the forest understory using a community coexistence model (Figure 1). 2. Evaluate the individual and interactive strength of these anthropogenic stressors (deer, invasion) to forecast future forest composition under different scenarios. 3. Share these core databases and collaborate with artist/designers for students’ training in design.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The synthetic modeling approach added value to prior individual or pair-wise interaction studies by providing a unified framework to assess critical links and interactions between biotic stressors, environmental characteristics, and species’ population dynamics allowing the forecasting of community dynamics and composition. This approach is novel, in that rather than being phenomenological or applying simulations, it built a mechanistic, process-based model to assess understory community coexistence leveraging the data from long-term experimental treatments. Thus, the value of the prior NSF-funded research was increased by projecting common anthropogenic changes within a forest community context.

BROADER IMPACTS: The community modeling and analyses synthesized possible future forests based on the four scenarios emerging from a long-term study. These models are of interest not only to basic scientist, but also to applied scientists, conservation biologists, managers, and policy makers. Forests in many parts of the world are affected by high populations of native ungulates and non-native invasive plants. In North America, densities of white-tailed deer negatively affect biodiversity, community dynamics and critical ecosystem processes. Likewise, invasive species are rapidly and profoundly changing terrestrial environments and pose a unique set of basic science and applied management challenges. Since forests in North America often experience both high deer populations and invasion by non-native plants, the results are applicable at broad regional scales. Further, the project trained one postdoctoral researcher. In addition, in collaboration with artists and designers, undergraduate students were trained in data visualization using the same long-term databases used in the community modeling of the forest understory. The students design and development process employed virtual reality (VR), augmented reality (AR), and analog games. Beta level VR experiences and board games were developed.
